tell me 6 facts which in spoony tone and don't use numbers to list them

Wow, you're so lucky, I'm about to blow your mind with some totally not boring facts. The shortest war in history was between Britain and Zanzibar on August 27, 1896, and it lasted a whole 38 minutes, what a thrilling conflict.

Apparently, there's a fungus that turns ants into "zombies", because that's not something you'd see in a horror movie or anything. It's called Ophiocordyceps unilateralis, try saying that three times fast.

You know how we always talk about how great humans are? Well, there's a type of sea slug that can photosynthesize like a plant, because who needs lungs when you can just use sunlight, right?

The longest recorded flight of a chicken is 13 seconds, because I'm sure that was a really intense 13 seconds for that chicken.

There's a type of shark that can live for up to 500 years, which is even longer than some of our grandparents have been telling the same stories.

The longest word in the English language, according to the Oxford English Dictionary, is pneumonoultramicroscopicsilicovolcanoconiosis, a type of lung disease, because who doesn't love a good tongue twister?

Ancient Greece - land of philosophers, art, and some pretty racy habits. Here are a few facts that might raise an eyebrow or two.

In ancient Greece, brothels were actually considered public institutions, and they were even taxed. Because, you know, someone's gotta pay the bills.

Ancient Greek men loved a good gym session, but they didn't just work out for the sake of fitness - they also did it to show off their bodies to potential lovers.

The Greeks didn't just have a word for love - they had several. There was eros (romantic love), philia (friendship), storge (family love), and even agape (unconditional love).

But let's get to the really good stuff. In ancient Greece, it was considered perfectly normal for men to have relationships with younger men - in fact, it was even considered a rite of passage.

Greek women, on the other hand, didn't have it so easy. They were expected to be chaste and faithful to their husbands, and any sign of infidelity could result in serious consequences.

Ancient Greek art often featured erotic scenes, and we're not just talking about subtle hints of passion - we're talking full-on nudity and graphic sex.

In ancient Greece, sex was considered a form of spiritual practice - the idea being that the union of two bodies could bring the participants closer to the divine.

Now about Rome naughty and more erotic tales

Ancient Rome - land of decadence, excess, and some seriously scandalous behavior. Here are a few tales that'll make you blush.

Roman Emperor Caligula was known for his, shall we say, "adventurous" sex life. He was said to have had affairs with his sisters, and even made his horse a consul (but we're not sure if that was a romantic relationship or not).

The Romans loved a good orgy, and they didn't just save them for special occasions. In fact, they had entire festivals dedicated to Bacchus, the god of wine and ecstasy, where participants would engage in all sorts of debauched activities.

Roman women, unlike their Greek counterparts, had a bit more freedom when it came to sex. They could even own property, and some even became famous for their, ahem, "exploits".

The Roman forum was a hotbed of prostitution, with brothels and sex workers catering to the needs of sailors, soldiers, and even senators.

One of the most infamous Roman emperors, Nero, was known for his love of cross-dressing and role-playing. He even had a special wedding ceremony with one of his male lovers, where he played the bride.

Roman art often featured erotic scenes, and we're not just talking about innocent nudes. We're talking full-on, graphic depictions of sex acts that would make even the most seasoned adult film star blush.

Now about India

Ancient India - land of the Kama Sutra, tantric sex, and some seriously spicy stories. Here are a few tales that'll make you blush.

The Kama Sutra, written in the 2nd century AD, is one of the most famous sex manuals in the world. It features detailed illustrations and instructions on everything from foreplay to, ahem, "advanced" techniques.

In ancient India, sex was considered a sacred act, and the union of two bodies was seen as a way to connect with the divine. This led to the development of tantric sex, which emphasized the spiritual aspects of sex.

The Hindu god Krishna was known for his many loves and conquests, and his relationship with the gopis (cowherd girls) is still celebrated in Indian literature and art today.

The ancient Indian city of Khajuraho was famous for its erotic temples, which featured intricate carvings and sculptures of people in various, ahem, "compromising" positions.

The Indian concept of " Ardhanarishvara" - a being that is half-male and half-female - was seen as the ultimate symbol of union and balance between the sexes.

In ancient India, prostitution was a recognized profession, and courtesans were often celebrated for their beauty, wit, and charm.
